body: NSVisualEffectView could be injected into NSWindow content view. The only problem is background of a web view, which should be transparent in order to view the NSVisualEffectView view.
Also see the webkit implementation which would allow such an effect in pure CSS, were it ported and included in Blink/Chromium. https://www.webkit.org/blog/3632/introducing-backdrop-filters/
:+1: +1 for the backdrop filters

The issue with using backdrop filters is that they wouldn't render through
to background apps. As far as I know the only way to achieve this feature
is the  use of a NSVisualEffectView or something custom. We could modify
backdrop filters to achieve this, but that may prove to be difficult.

On Tue, Oct 6, 2015 at 7:47 AM dkfiresky notifications@github.com wrote:

> [image: :+1:] +1 for the backdrop filters
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/3002#issuecomment-145880100.
@wisesascha Ah, I figured they'd probably cover that. Not sure how that would work.
Having the ability to easily toggle vibrancy will bring apps under OS X even closer to native. :+1: on adding this effect as a toggle.
For everyone interested in Vibrancy effect I've made a small example on how to do it https://github.com/evgenyzinoviev/electron-vibrancy-demo/

Being able to enable blur purely on the Mac window behind BrowserWindow would be huge.  No need to support HTML blur - the right blur effect would blur against the Mac's background.  It would give Electron apps a native feel which could be visible in any part of the HTML page simply by using background:transparent;  Consider this a vote for enabling this alongside transparent:true with something like transparent_blur: 10;
Count :+1: for me as well. Is there anything in particular that would prevent this from shipping if somebody were to formalize the example by @evgenyzinoviev into a pull request?

It would be really quite nice if @evgenyzinoviev or anyone else with understanding of [**NSVisualEffectView**](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/Foundation/Reference/NSVisualEffectView_Class/) opted to submit a PR for Vibrancy. Had I the ability and experience, I'd work on this.

This is an enhancement many will utilize.

Vibrancy depends on enabled transparency, and since 0.36 (or since Chromium 47, more precisely) Electron has troubles with it. Right now I'm writing a project that has blurred transparent window and I'm forced to stick to 0.35 with patches because of that.

I'm going to contribute this feature to Electron someday if nobody overtake me, but with transparency bug now it looks pretty terrible. I hope that Chromium guys will fix it. That is what should be done at first.
Super interested in this are the transparency issues still present?
@tommoor yes. Compared to Chromium 47, 49th is much better but still not perfect. There is related issue: https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/4157

+1
Before porting my app to electron, in Xcode I simply put a NSVisualEffectView behind a web view with a transparent background. It might not have been the 'right' way to do it but it worked. Now I'm stuck with a white background.
![schermata 2016-06-10 alle 01 17 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19847464/15949617/2e81ba9e-2ea9-11e6-8931-fcd27f22d2a4.png)

Is there an official stance from the Electron team on this? 

Any stance it better than none. If you're not willing to get this in, just let us know.
Nobody on Electron team is against this, someone submit a PR :)

Not sure how relevant this is, but my Chrome just updated to 52 (latest version mentioned in this issue is 49) and includes vibrancy in the tab bar:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/174864/17598508/e8ca50be-5fc8-11e6-80ac-08a0532fc800.png)
@knpwrs The tab bar is rendered natively (i.e is not HTML), so it doesn't help us much :cry:

I'm just going to leave this here…
https://github.com/evgenyzinoviev/electron/commit/7417821ad8f7ff6e9c669a3c3da35133c128f160
Hey guys! Any updates?
It would be awesome if this gets implemented. In Windows 10, I think it is possible using `SetWindowCompositionAttribute`
`SetWindowCompositionAttribute` is undocumented API
Has there been any progress on this? Have the upstream chromium transparency issues been resolved as of Electron 1.4.0 / Chromium 53? Looking forward to this.

This will be a fantastic visual effect. I tried with `BrowserWindow.webPreferences.experimentalFeatures=true` and then use css3 filter `-webkit-backdrop-filter:blur(1px)`. But still no luck. Wait for someone's PR

@stanleyxu2005 
try **`app.commandLine.appendSwitch('--enable-experimental-web-platform-features');`** 
in **`main.js`**, use **`backdrop-filter: blur(10px);`** in CSS
It works and here's the screenshot taken on Linux
[![Selection_259.png](https://s14.postimg.org/z0xnba5y9/Selection_259.png)](https://postimg.org/image/6o25ktk7x/)

**EDIT : I know this is completely different than window vibrancy but might be helpful for folks trying to get a backdrop filter effect :D**
@akashwoz it's not what this ticket is about. Window vibrancy effect is something completely different than backdrop blur.

Hey guys, until this gets implemented in Electron,I am presenting a very hacky way to achieve this effect. Basically create a native addon, feed the native window handle, call native APIs to create the vibrant view. It works on **Windows,MacOS** but see the readme about limitations,I'll eventually implement Linux version too.

Here is a screenshot:

![](http://i.imgur.com/yvkK4mY.png)

The addon uses `SetWindowCompositionAttribute` on Windows 10, which is a private API, meaning that Microsoft can change this API any time and break the addons functionality. `SetWindowCompositionAttribute` is being used by OS for blurring behind the start menu, notification center etc.  
Here is the addon [electron-vibrancy](https://github.com/arkenthera/electron-vibrancy)

Edit: Updated to reflect current state of the addon.
Hey. It's awesome! Thanks for addon. So we will wait MacOs support.
@arkenthera Would this https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/7460#issuecomment-254989875 by @zcbenz help with support for macOS?

Update: Mac version of [electron-vibrancy](https://github.com/arkenthera/electron-vibrancy) will be live probably this weekend. You can try the test app on mac now and get something like this.

![](http://i.imgur.com/J59ptMC.png)

Also light/dark materials are available through options object. Thanks for @scherii for his help on testing.
@arkenthera Would you be willing to submit a PR for this?
Edit: FYI #7898 has been merged.
Fixed by #7898 and released in 1.4.7, closing this out.
